case_name: Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd. v. Government of India

facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 464 of 1965 by special leave from the order dated October 17, 1964 of the Government of India, Ministry of Steel and Mines.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 464 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the order dated October 17, 1964, of the Government of India, Ministry of Steel and Mines, Department of Mines and Metals on an application under Rule 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules 1960.

facts.text: Appellant is Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd., a public limited company engaged in mining manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd., is a public limited companypany engaged in mining manganese ore.

facts.text: On February 5, 1941, Rai Bahadur Bansilal Abirchand took a lease of 216 acres and 92 cents land in Government Forest, East Pench Range, Tahsil Ramtek, Nagpur from Governor of Central Provinces and Berar for 15 years commencing September 10, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: On February 5, 1941, one Rai Bahadur Bansilal Abirchand took a lease of a land of extent 216 acres and 92 cents in the Government Forest, East Pench Range, in the Tahsil of Ramtek in the District of Nagpur, from the Governor of Central Provinces and Berar for a term of 15 years companymencing from September 10, 1940.

facts.text: Under indenture dated March 4, 1952, appellant obtained transfer of the leasehold interest from successors of Bansilal Abirchand.

anchor.surface_text: Under an indenture dated March 4, 1952, the appellant obtained a transfer of the said leasehold interest from the successors in interest of the said Bansilal Abirchand.

facts.text: After transfer, appellant entered possession of the land and spent about Rs. 10,00,000 developing for mining.

anchor.surface_text: After the transfer, the appellant entered into possession of the said extent of land and is alleged to have spent about Rs. 10,00,000 for the purpose of developing the area to carry out the mining operation.

facts.text: Lease was to expire on September 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The said lease was to expire on September 9, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant applied for renewal of lease for 20 years to Secretary to Government, Commerce and Industries Department, Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: On the expiry of the said lease the appellant applied for the renewal of the lease for a further period of 20 years to the appropriate authority, namely, the Secretary to Government, Commerce and Industries Department, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur.

facts.text: By letter dated September 2, 1958, offer on special duty informed appellant that renewal would not be granted.

anchor.surface_text: After a protracted companyrespondence companyering a period of about 3 years, the offer on special duty, Industries and Co-operation Department, State of Bombay, informed the appellant by letter dated September 2, 1958, that the said renewal companyld number be granted.

facts.text: Revision against that order dismissed by Central Government on December 14, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a revision against that order to the Central Government, but that was dismissed on December 14, 1958.

facts.text: On April 9, 1959, State of Bombay issued notification calling for applications for lease of the mines.

anchor.surface_text: On April 9, 1959, the State of Bombay issued a numberification calling for applications from the public in respect of the least of the said mines.

facts.text: On May 15, 1959, appellant filed application for 20-year lease.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15, 1959, the appellant filed an application for the grant of a lease for a period of 20 years in respect of the said mines.

facts.text: On July 8, 1959, Government of Bombay granted entire area to appellant, informed by letter July 14, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On July 8, 1959, the Government of Bombay made an order -ranting the entire area of the said mines to the appellant and by letter dated July 14, 1959, informed him of the same.

facts.text: During 1960, State of Bombay divided into Maharashtra and Gujarat; mines fell in Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: During the year 1960 the territories forming part of the State of Bombay were divided and the State of Maharashtra and the State of Gujarat came into being and the said mines fell in the Maharashtra State.

facts.text: On August 25, 1960, Maharashtra Government notified mines reserved for public sector exploitation.

anchor.surface_text: On August 25, 1960, the Maharashtra Government issued a numberification for the information of the public that the said mines were reserved for the exploitation of minerals in the public sector.

facts.text: On January 16, 1961, Collector of Nagpur informed appellant application rejected as mines reserved for State.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on January 16, 1961, the Collector of Nagpur informed the appellant that its application for the ,ease of the mines was rejected as the mines in question fell in a block reserved for State exploitation.

facts.text: On March 11, 1961, appellant filed revision to Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1961, the appellant filed a revision to the Central Government against the said order.

facts.text: On June 22, 1961, Central Government informed appellant to pursue reconsideration with Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: On June 22, 1961, the Central Government informed the appellant that instructions had been issued to the Government of Maharashtra... for reconsidering its application.

facts.text: By letter December 19, 1961, Maharashtra rejected appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated December 19, 1961, the Government of Maharashtra informed the appellant that its application for the mining lease had been rejected.

facts.text: On February 17, 1962, appellant filed revision to Central Government against Maharashtra order.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant on or about February 17, 1962, filed a revision application before the Central Government against the said order of the Government of Maharashtra.

facts.text: On October 17, 1964, Central Government rejected the revision.

anchor.surface_text: On October 17, 1964, the Central Government rejected the revision application.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra issued notification dated March 26, 1965 inviting applications; appellant submitted application.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated in the companynter-affidavit filed by the Central Government that subsequently the Government of Maharashtra... had issued a numberification dated March 26, 1965, inviting applications... the appellant has submitted its application.

facts.text: The fact of fresh notification and appellant's application is not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: This is number disputed.

facts.text: Order of Bombay Govt July 14, 1959 was recommendation, not grant, as no prior approval of Central Govt.

anchor.surface_text: the Government of Bombay by its order dated July 14, 1959, granted... Admittedly, numbersuch approval was obtained. The said order can, therefore, only be companystrued at best to be a recommendation.

facts.text: Central Government order dated October 17, 1964 rejected revision after considering grounds, agreeing with Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated October 17, 1964, the Central Government rejected the revision application stating I am directed to refer... after careful companysideration... numbervalid ground for interfering.

facts.text: Maharashtra order December 19, 1961 gave full reasons for rejection.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated December 19, 1961, the State Government of Maharashtra rejected the appellants application... gave full reasons.

If it was a tribunal, this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution can entertain an appeal against the order of the Central Government made in exercise of its revisional powers under r. 55 of the Rules.

holdings.text: The Central Government, when exercising revisional powers under Rule 55 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1960, acts as a tribunal amenable to appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The entire scheme of the rules posits a judicial procedure and the Central Government is constituted as a tribunal to dispose of the said revision. Indeed, this Court in Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India ruled that the Central Government, exercising its power of review under r. 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, was acting judicially as a tribunal. The new rule, if at all, is clearer in that regard and emphasizes the judicial character of the proceeding. If it was a tribunal, this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution can entertain an appeal against the order of the Central Government made in exercise of its revisional powers under r. 55 of the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Rules 54 and 55 requires calling records, considering comments, giving opportunity to represent; precedent in Shivji Nathubhai confirms judicial functioning.

holdings.text: The Central Government's order dated October 17, 1964 rejecting the revision is not invalid for lack of reasons as it states careful consideration and no valid ground for interference, agreeing with the fully reasoned State Government order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: State order provided full reasons; Central order indicates agreement and no valid ground; distinguishes Harinagar Sugar Mills where reversal lacked reasons entirely.

holdings.text: The appellant was not entitled as of right to a personal hearing before the Central Government; opportunity under Rule 55 proviso satisfied by written representation.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second contention, I do not think that the appellant is entitled as of right to a personal hearing. It is no doubt a principle of natural justice that a quasi-judicial tribunal cannot make any decision adverse to a party without giving him an effective opportunity of meeting any relevant allegations against him. Indeed, r. 55 of the Rules... recognize the said principle... The said opportunity need not necessarily be by personal hearing. It can be by written representation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 55 proviso requires opportunity to represent against State comments; personal hearing discretionary, written suffices for natural justice.

holdings.text: The principles of natural justice were complied with by the Central Government in disposing of the revision.

anchor.surface_text: The order is bad also because it has not complied with the principles of natural justice, namely,... As regards the second contention, I do not think that the appellant is entitled as of right to a personal hearing... The facts of the present case disclose that a written representation would effectively meet the requirements of the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Opportunity given via written representation against State comments as per Rule 55; no extraneous matters proven withheld.

holdings.text: The Government of Bombay's order dated July 14, 1959 was only a recommendation and not a valid grant of mining lease as no previous approval of Central Government obtained under Section 8(2) for manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: the Government of Bombay by its order dated July 14, 1959, granted... Admittedly, no such approval was obtained. The said order can, therefore, only be construed at best to be a recommendation to the Central Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 8(2) mandates previous Central approval for manganese lease; absence makes State order ineffective as grant.

holdings.text: Section 17 of the Mines and Minerals Act has no bearing as it applies only where Central Government proposes to undertake prospecting or mining operations itself.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can I agree with the contention of the learned counsel based upon s. 17 of the Act... Section 17 of the Act has nothing to do with public or private sector it applies only to a specific case where the Central Government proposes to undertake prospecting or mining operations in any area not already held under any prospecting licence or mining lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of Section 17 limited to Central Govt's own operations; no such proposal here, reservation for public sector otherwise permissible.

holdings.text: This is not a fit case for exercise of this Court's discretionary jurisdiction under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: I do not think that this is a fit case for our interference in the exercise of our discretionary jurisdiction. The appeal is dismissed... We agree that a this is not a fit case for interference under Art. 136 of the Constitution...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fresh applications invited by Maharashtra, appellant applied; interference would complicate matters and harm public interest.

holdings.text: An administrative tribunal's order rejecting revision is not invalid solely for lack of reasons, especially when affirming a reasoned lower order, even if appealable under Article 136.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.136 appeals treat courts/tribunals same; in limine dismissals lack reasons; Harinagar inapplicable as involved unreasoned reversal.

precedents.citation: Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 1 ruled that the Central Government, exercising its power of review under r. 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, was acting judicially as a tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government exercising power of review under r. 54 of Mineral Concession Rules 1949 acting judicially as tribunal

precedents.citation: M S. Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 2

anchor.surface_text: M S. Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 2 went further and held that, as the decision of the Central Government was subject to an appeal to the Supreme Court under Art. 136

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd v Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government decision subject to appeal under Art. 136 must give reasons for its order

precedents.citation: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1

anchor.surface_text: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1 If the Central Government acts as a tribunal exercising judicial powers and the exercise of that power is subject to the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd v Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government acting as tribunal under Art. 136 jurisdiction must give reasons for order
precedents.cited_holding: If the Central Government acts as a tribunal exercising judicial powers and the exercise of that power is subject to the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution, we fail to see how the power of this Court can be effectively exercised if reasons are not given by the Central Government in support of its order.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances I do not think that this is a fit case for our interference in the exercise of our discretionary jurisdiction. The appeal is dismissed, but in the circumstances of the case, without costs. Bachawat J. We agree that the appeal should be dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against the Central Government's order rejecting the revision application dismissed; no interference under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: unication of the order to him apply to the Central Government for the revision of the order. A companyrt- fee is prescribed for the said revision. Rul

edges.explanation: The holding determines the true nature of the power under Rule 55, directly addressing the issue of amenability to Article 136 appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The entire scheme of the rules posits a judicial procedure and the Central Government is constituted as a tribunal to dispose of the said revision. Indeed, this Court in Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India ruled that the Central Government, exercising its power of review under r. 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, was acting judicially as a tribunal. The new rule, if at all, is clearer in that regard and emphasizes the judicial character of the proceeding. If it was a tribunal, this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution can entertain an appeal against the order of the Central Government made in exercise of its revisional powers under r. 55 of the Rules.

In the circumstances I do not think that this is a fit case for our interference in the exercise of our discretionary jurisdiction. The appeal is dismissed, but in the circumstances of the case, without costs. Bachawat J. We agree that the appeal should be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second contention, I do not think that the appellant is entitled as of right to a personal hearing. It is no doubt a principle of natural justice that a quasi-judicial tribunal cannot make any decision adverse to a party without giving him an effective opportunity of meeting any relevant allegations against him. Indeed, r. 55 of the Rules... recognize the said principle... The said opportunity need not necessarily be by personal hearing. It can be by written representation.

In the circumstances I do not think that this is a fit case for our interference in the exercise of our discretionary jurisdiction. The appeal is dismissed, but in the circumstances of the case, without costs. Bachawat J. We agree that the appeal should be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can I agree with the contention of the learned counsel based upon s. 17 of the Act... Section 17 of the Act has nothing to do with public or private sector it applies only to a specific case where the Central Government proposes to undertake prospecting or mining operations in any area not already held under any prospecting licence or mining lease.

In the circumstances I do not think that this is a fit case for our interference in the exercise of our discretionary jurisdiction. The appeal is dismissed, but in the circumstances of the case, without costs. Bachawat J. We agree that the appeal should be dismissed.
